text: Charles-François Angelet (18 November 1797 – 20 December 1832) was a Flemish pianist and composer. ==Life== Angelet was born in Ghent in 1797; his parents were Robert Angelet, organist of the parish church of , and his wife Angeline van Wichelen. His father was his first music teacher; at age seven, he gave a concert. Aged seventeen, he was appointed organist of a church in Wetteren, near Ghent. In 1821 he went to the Conservatoire de Paris; he studied piano with Pierre-Joseph-Guillaume Zimmerman, harmony and accompaniment with Victor Dourlen, and composition with François-Joseph Fétis, the director of the conservatoire, who thought he was a promising composer. In 1822 he won first prize in a piano competition at the conservatoire, and was appointed répétiteur.Angelet, Charles-François Studiecentrum voor Vlaamse Muziek. Retrieved 29 March 2019. He moved to Brussels, where he was a piano teacher at the Royal Music School. In 1829 he became pianist of the court of William I of the Netherlands. After a period of failing health he died in Ghent in 1832, aged 35. ==Compositions== Angelet wrote a symphony that won a prize in Ghent in 1820. His other compositions are mostly piano music; he also wrote a piano trio and some songs. Fétis wrote, "Angelet had originality in his ideas, and wrote with elegance and purity". ==References== Category:1797 births Category:1832 deaths Category:Belgian classical pianists Category:19th-century classical pianists Category:Belgian male classical composers Category:19th- century classical composers Category:People from Ghent Category:Conservatoire de Paris alumni Category:Male classical pianists Category:19th-century male musicians
title: Charles-François Angelet
